lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion – Robert Cialdini.pdf

reinforcements.similarity: Both leverage active contribution as a commitment device. works-005 engineers 'host-as-advisor' moments where the host contributes expertise (not just data) to lock commitment through self-concept consistency. rb-ui-001's Mutual Pledge Card applies the same principle to BOTH parties: writing a personal pledge is an act of active contribution that shifts self-image from 'someone who booked a place' to 'someone who personally committed to this arrangement.'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (inside-out): Andreas shifts from questioner to advisor at 5:12 ('if they just go there to sleep, I think just a bed') — this unprompted contribution IS the commitment moment. Reverse-benchmark evidence (outside-in): Cialdini Ch.3 identifies four properties of maximally effective commitments — active, public, effortful, internally motivated. The Chinese POW camp research showed written self-disclosure produces the strongest commitments. Six transcript speakers independently express consequences of missing mutual commitment: Michael Spear ('How do I know you're gonna do that?'), Patricia ('scammed twice'), Hemeden ('make sure they're not crazy'). Combined: the advisor moment (works-005) creates commitment through expertise contribution on the HOST side. The mutual pledge (rb-ui-001) creates commitment through personal self-disclosure on BOTH sides. Together they define a complete commitment architecture: hosts commit through expertise, guests commit through self-introduction, and both commit through mutual pledges.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Very high. Two different theoretical frameworks (Kahneman's System 1/System 2 and Cialdini's commitment/consistency) independently identify active contribution as the mechanism that converts evaluation into commitment. The convergence across frameworks significantly increases confidence that contribution-based commitment is a real, exploitable psychological mechanism.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the proposal/acceptance phase where two parties formalize an arrangement. communicates-005 prescribes pre-packaged proposals presented as confirmations (not constructions) for the host. rb-ui-001 extends this by adding a visible, mutual commitment artifact where BOTH parties write personal pledges to each other. The existing element optimizes the host's cognitive experience of proposals; the new element optimizes the psychological BINDING of both parties to the arrangement.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence (inside-out): Andreas processes Bryant's pre-packaged proposal with ease because it is a confirmation task, not a construction task (andreas-call.txt, 1:58-2:19). Reverse-benchmark evidence (outside-in): Airbnb's Instant Book scores zero on Cialdini's four commitment-strength dimensions. Combined insight: proposals must be EASY to process (communicates-005) AND psychologically BINDING through mutual investment (rb-ui-001). Ease without commitment produces fast but fragile agreements. Commitment without ease produces strong but abandoned flows. Note: a sequencing tension exists — see contradictions section.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: High. The design-stack evidence says 'make proposals effortless to accept.' The reverse-benchmark evidence says 'make arrangements psychologically binding through mutual commitment.' These are complementary, not contradictory — but require careful sequencing (one-tap acceptance first, optional pledge enrichment second).

reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust-building through evidence rather than claims. communicates-003 prescribes a Trust Credential Stack where process evidence (credit checks, vetting, pre-authorization) precedes promises. rb-ui-002 creates a different kind of evidence: similarity-matched social proof from guests in the same situation. Both replace 'trust us' with 'here is evidence you can evaluate yourself.'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas trusts the payment guarantee not because Bryant says 'we guarantee' but because Bryant explains HOW (credit check, vetting, pre-authorization at 3:28-3:51). Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.4 shows social proof is most persuasive from similar others — the Columbia wallet experiment showed 70% return rates from similar finders vs. 33% from dissimilar. Susan Bryant demands physical inspection because aggregate reviews don't resolve HER uncertainty. Combined: two types of evidence build trust — process evidence ('here is how we verified this person') and peer evidence ('here is what people like you experienced'). Process evidence addresses 'is the system reliable?' Peer evidence addresses 'will this work for someone like me?'
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate-to-strong. The design-stack identified process transparency as the trust mechanism (Kahneman's causal coherence). The reverse-benchmark identified similarity-filtered social proof as the trust mechanism (Cialdini's similarity principle). These are genuinely different mechanisms addressing different aspects of trust — system trust vs. outcome trust.

reinforcements.similarity: Both redesign the review system but from different ends. guest-communicates-007 optimizes review COLLECTION (batch at natural reflection points instead of per-stay prompts to avoid ego depletion). rb-ui-002 optimizes review DISPLAY (filter by similarity to surface the most persuasive social proof). Better collection feeds better display — they form an end-to-end review system redesign.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Kahneman's ego depletion — 13 sequential review prompts for a 13-week lease drain System 2, producing skipped or perfunctory late reviews. Batching at Week 4, midpoint, and final produces higher-quality data. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.4 similarity principle — social proof from similar others is dramatically more persuasive than aggregate ratings. Combined: higher-quality reviews from batched collection (design-stack) become the raw material for similarity-filtered display (reverse-benchmark). The design-stack optimized the input side; the reverse-benchmark optimized the output side.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate. The connection is architectural (input → output of the same system) rather than direct psychological overlap. Both independently validated but addressing different aspects of the review lifecycle. A future run should address the middle layer: review PROMPT design that deliberately collects similarity-taggable metadata (stay purpose, duration, work pattern) to bridge collection and display.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address design at phase transitions. works-001 prescribes System 1 trust gates through visual continuity and recognition at every transition. rb-ui-003 creates a structured communication architecture for the acceptance-to-move-in transition — the highest-anxiety gap in the guest journey where the platform currently goes silent.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: each phase transition must signal continuity with the prior phase through visual consistency, familiar language, and explicit connection to what just happened. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.4 pluralistic ignorance — the blank messaging interface shows no evidence that other guests communicate, so both parties default to silence. Tammy: 'Airbnb just kind of leaves you to your own devices.' Combined: the acceptance-to-move-in transition is not just a visual/cognitive transition (works-001) but a COMMUNICATION transition. The platform must provide both visual continuity (design-stack) AND structured conversation norms (reverse-benchmark).
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Strong. The design-stack identified the VISUAL dimension of transitions (System 1 trust gates). The reverse-benchmark identified the SOCIAL dimension of transitions (structured communication to overcome pluralistic ignorance). These are orthogonal — both needed to fully design a successful transition.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the gap between proposal acceptance and the active stay. guest-behaves-004 provides status visibility during the proposal WAIT (anxiety-resolving status stream). rb-ui-003 provides structured communication topics AFTER acceptance (trust-building micro-commitments). They are sequential: guest-behaves-004 resolves waiting anxiety during negotiation, then rb-ui-003 fills post-acceptance silence.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Guest enters waiting state with no visibility, forcing continuous System 2 monitoring. Status display resolves this by answering 'who acts next?' Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.4 pluralistic ignorance + Ch.3 micro-commitments. Post-acceptance silence suppresses trust-building communication; structured prompts create layered micro-commitments that compound into mutual trust. Combined: design-stack resolves the anxiety of WAITING. Reverse-benchmark resolves the silence of POST-ACCEPTANCE. Together they create continuous engagement from proposal to move-in.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: High. Both validated from different sources and different frameworks (Kahneman's System 1/2 vs. Cialdini's social proof + micro-commitment). They address consecutive phases of the same emotional arc: waiting-anxiety → acceptance-silence → arrival-preparation.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the psychological danger of dead-end moments. feels-006 prescribes that every interaction close must include confirmation of accomplishment + preview of what comes next (forward momentum). rb-ui-004 applies this exact principle to the most psychologically potent close in the entire journey: the post-review moment, where the guest's public positive commitment creates peak consistency pressure.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Interactions ending with 'Done' dissipate momentum. The solution: relief of completion + curiosity of continuation. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.3 lowball principle — the moment after a public positive commitment is when consistency pressure is highest. Deutsch and Gerard showed public commitments produce the most persistent behavior. Combined: the design-stack discovered the general principle (forward momentum at every close). The reverse-benchmark discovered the specific highest-value application (post-review commitment peak). rb-ui-004 is the most psychologically potent instance of the feels-006 principle.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Very high. This is the strongest cross-process reinforcement in the run. The general interaction design principle (Kahneman: forward momentum) and the specific psychological mechanism (Cialdini: post-commitment consistency pressure) converge on the same design moment. Neither pipeline alone would have both identified the principle AND pinpointed its optimal application.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the mismatch between the user's mental model and the platform's data model. works-006 prescribes translating between the host's mental model (monthly rent, 'walk-up') and the platform's data model (nightly rates, property types). rb-ui-005 captures the guest's mental model ('I'm a remote worker who needs a quiet workspace') and reflects it back throughout search, preventing the preference amnesia that forces guests to do mental translation work.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas thinks in monthly rent and 'walk-up' descriptions, not nightly rates and property categories (andreas-call.txt, 1:03-1:10, 3:02-3:16). Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.3 — written commitments are dramatically stronger than mental ones. Tom C's broken search, Steven Mariscal's $1200/month mental math, Tyler Wood's Craigslist workaround all confirm preference amnesia is real. Combined: format translation must happen on BOTH sides. Hosts need native-format input (works-006). Guests need preference externalization and reflection (rb-ui-005). The platform mediates between both mental models.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Strong. The host-side mental model mismatch (design-stack) and the guest-side preference amnesia (reverse-benchmark) are mirror images of the same fundamental problem: the platform forces users to think in its language instead of their own.

reinforcements.similarity: Both operate at discovery/search and concern how the platform sets initial expectations. guest-feels-006 prescribes honest expectation-setting to prevent downstream betrayal ('mid-term housing with proposal-based booking' not 'book your perfect space now'). rb-ui-005 captures the guest's self-definition as a micro-commitment that shapes the entire journey.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Discovery messaging that primes expectations ('easy, flexible housing') is violated by mid-lease friction, creating cognitive dissonance. The solution is honest, specific expectation-setting. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.3 foot-in-the-door — trivially small self-definitional commitments at discovery produce 3x increases in follow-through. Combined: guest-feels-006 says 'don't lie about what you are.' rb-ui-005 says 'ask who THEY are.' Both improve discovery from complementary angles — honesty (design-stack) and commitment-capture (reverse-benchmark).
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate. Different frameworks addressing the same moment from complementary angles. guest-feels-006 prevents harm; rb-ui-005 creates opportunity. The combination yields a discovery experience that is both honest AND commitment-building.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional architecture of financial commitment moments. feels-002 prescribes 'relief of guaranteed income' for hosts (show the money, then show why it's safe). rb-ui-006 provides social proof reassurance for GUESTS at their commitment moment (proposal submission).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas's emotional arc shifts at 3:28-3:51 when Bryant explains the payment guarantee mechanism. The relief of 'my money is safe' converts evaluation into commitment. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini Ch.4 — social proof is most influential during uncertainty. The proposal submission is the guest's peak uncertainty moment. Tom C's pricing confusion and Theodore's anxiety about committing validate that this moment lacks psychological support. Combined: BOTH sides of the marketplace experience a peak-uncertainty financial commitment moment. Hosts need relief through mechanism explanation (feels-002). Guests need reassurance through social proof (rb-ui-006). Together they define bilateral emotional architecture for the proposal flow.
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Strong. Design-stack identified the HOST's emotional need at financial commitment. Reverse-benchmark identified the GUEST's emotional need at financial commitment. Together they define a bilateral emotional architecture: hosts feel relief, guests feel reassurance.

reinforcements.similarity: Both place trust signals at decision moments. communicates-003 prescribes process evidence before promises (credit check → verification → guarantee). rb-ui-006 places social proof evidence at the proposal submission screen (host rating, acceptance rate). Both follow the principle: specific evidence > generic reassurance.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Design-stack evidence: Andreas responds to trust mechanisms with verifiable standards ('excellent credit on every single tenant'). He trusts PROCESS, not promises. Reverse-benchmark evidence: Cialdini shows social proof is most powerful at peak uncertainty. The checkout/proposal moment is a category-wide trust vacuum. Combined: trust at decision moments requires BOTH process evidence (communicates-003: 'the system is reliable') AND social evidence (rb-ui-006: 'other people trusted this and it worked out').
reinforcements.confidence_boost: Moderate-high. Different trust modalities (process vs. social) addressing the same decision moment. Together they create a more complete trust architecture than either alone.

contradictions.conflict: communicates-005 prescribes that the host's proposal experience should be a CONFIRMATION task ('accept with one tap'), optimized for depleted System 2. rb-ui-001 introduces a Mutual Pledge Card that requires the host to WRITE a personal welcome message — an effortful, active task. Tension: the library says 'minimize host effort at proposal stage' while the new element says 'require meaningful host effort at acceptance stage.'
contradictions.evidence_comparison: communicates-005 has strong design-stack evidence (Kahneman's depletion research, Andreas's call). rb-ui-001 has strong reverse-benchmark evidence (Cialdini's four commitment-strength properties, 6+ transcript validations). Both have strong evidence; neither can be dismissed.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve through sequencing, not elimination. Proposal acceptance remains a one-tap confirmation (communicates-005). The mutual pledge is a SEPARATE step after acceptance, strongly encouraged but optional. Frame as: 'You've accepted — now welcome your guest personally.' Provide smart defaults pre-filled from listing details so the depleted host can accept defaults (communicates-005 principle) while the invested host can personalize (rb-ui-001 principle). This preserves cognitive ease of acceptance while adding commitment architecture of the pledge.

contradictions.conflict: feels-001 prescribes maximum cognitive ease in the first 2 seconds — minimal information density, one recognizable anchor. rb-ui-002 adds filter chips, summary statistics, and segment-specific review counts to the listing page, potentially increasing cognitive load at first glance.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: feels-001 has strong design-stack evidence (Kahneman's cognitive ease research). rb-ui-002 has strong reverse-benchmark evidence (Cialdini's similarity principle, Columbia wallet experiment). The conflict is real: more social proof means more information means more cognitive load.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve through progressive disclosure. Listing page loads with AGGREGATE review score only (feels-001: cognitive ease, one number). Similarity-filtered view is available on interaction: filter chips appear below the aggregate, selecting one reveals segment-specific data. The auto-suggested 'people like you' chip provides a gentle nudge but does not clutter the default view. This preserves the 2-second cognitive ease requirement while making similarity filtering available one tap deeper.

extensions.gap_filled: Similarity-filtered social proof — a completely new psychological dimension not present in the existing library. The library's trust framework is built on Kahneman's System 1/System 2 (how information is processed) but does not address Cialdini's similarity principle (which information is most persuasive). rb-ui-002 introduces the concept that showing reviews from 'people like you' is dramatically more persuasive than aggregate ratings, implemented as filterable review chips by stay-context categories (Remote Workers, Traveling Nurses, Relocating, 4+ Week Stays, Solo Guests).
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence from behavioral framework (Cialdini's similarity principle — wallet experiment, Werther effect, Tommy swimming anecdote). Moderate confidence from transcript validation (Susan Bryant's physical inspection workaround, Hemeden's 'make sure they're not crazy'). Lower confidence on implementation feasibility — requires sufficient review volume with tagged stay-context metadata.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes. Search call transcripts for explicit similarity-seeking language: guests asking 'has anyone like me stayed here?' or hosts asking 'what kind of person is this?' Also validate that the review PROMPT design can collect the metadata (stay purpose, duration context, priority satisfaction) that rb-ui-002's filter chips need.

extensions.gap_filled: Mutual bilateral commitment architecture. The existing library has strong one-directional commitment elements (works-005 for host advisor moment, communicates-005 for proposal confirmation) but no element that creates SIMULTANEOUS visible commitment from both host and guest. rb-ui-001's split-screen Mutual Pledge Card is a genuinely new structural pattern with no precedent in the library.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Strongest transcript validation in the run (Layer 2 'strong' with 6+ independent speakers). Cialdini Ch.3 framework support is unambiguous. Split Lease's existing counter-proposal flow already creates more mutual investment than Airbnb's Instant Book, making the Mutual Pledge a natural extension.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Partially validated already through Layer 2 cross-referencing. A future run could specifically test host reception of guest self-introduction at the proposal stage — the host-side response to guest disclosure is not yet validated.

extensions.gap_filled: Host-guest communication as a designed experience. The library treats communication as a channel characteristic (communicates-006) and notification architecture (guest-communicates-005). NO element addresses host-guest PEER communication as a designed, structured experience with guided topics, pre-filled templates, and social proof about norms. rb-ui-003 fills this gap with a conversation guide using social proof ('Most guests discuss these topics') to break pluralistic ignorance and structured prompts to create micro-commitments.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence. Tammy's 'Airbnb just leaves you to your own devices' is the most cited competitor complaint. Cialdini's pluralistic ignorance research directly predicts that unstructured communication leads to silence. Strong transcript evidence + strong framework support + clear competitive gap = high confidence.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: The communication gap is validated. The specific topic structure (Arrival Details, Workspace Setup, House Rhythm, Neighborhood Tips) needs validation through actual host-guest message analysis to confirm these topics predict stay satisfaction.

extensions.gap_filled: Post-review forward commitment bridge AND guest identity infrastructure. No existing library element addresses the post-stay moment or builds a guest identity narrative. rb-ui-004 introduces: (1) reflecting the guest's own review back as a commitment anchor, (2) three forward-commitment paths (save host, see availability, share), and (3) a guest identity line ('You've stayed with 3 hosts across 2 cities') that creates self-concept consistency pressure for retention.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium-high confidence on the commitment bridge (Cialdini's lowball principle is well-established). Medium confidence on guest identity (Freedman/Fraser experiment provides strong theoretical support but no direct user evidence exists for identity-based retention on Split Lease). The post-review moment has the weakest transcript validation (disappoint-007 at 'weak') because call transcripts capture pre-stay interactions, not post-stay.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Yes — highest priority for future validation. Search for: (1) post-stay guest interview data, (2) review text that reveals identity language ('I'm a Split Lease person'), (3) rebooking behavior data to understand what currently triggers repeat use. The identity line is the most ambitious extension in the run and the most hypothesis-dependent.

extensions.gap_filled: Discovery-phase commitment device for guests. The existing library has strong discovery elements for hosts (works-001, works-004, communicates-006) but the GUEST discovery experience has no commitment architecture. rb-ui-005 creates the micro-commitment ('What brings you here?' + 'What matters most?') that Cialdini's foot-in-the-door research predicts will shift the guest from anonymous browser to self-defined seeker.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong confidence. Cialdini's telephone tactic ('How are you feeling tonight?') nearly doubled compliance. Sherman's prediction technique produced 700% increase in volunteering. Five transcript quotes validate preference amnesia (Tom C, Steven Mariscal, Tyler Wood). Theoretical + competitive + transcript evidence all converge.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Lower priority. The principle is well-validated. The specific implementation (three purpose options, priority chips, persistent preference bar) needs usability testing to confirm the micro-commitment does not become a conversion barrier.

extensions.gap_filled: Social proof at the peak commitment moment. No existing element provides social proof specifically at the proposal submission screen. communicates-003 provides process-based trust signals but not social proof. guest-feels-002 prevents price betrayal but doesn't add positive reassurance. rb-ui-006 fills the specific gap of the 'checkout desert' (disappoint-002) — the absence of any psychological support at the moment money is committed.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Cialdini Ch.4 is explicit that social proof peaks in influence during uncertainty. Layer 2 validated the checkout desert at 'moderate' level (Tom C's pricing confusion, Theodore's pre-commitment anxiety). The element is also low-effort to implement (a compact badge with two dynamic stats) with high potential impact.
extensions.needs_design_stack_validation: Lower priority. The principle is well-established. Implementation primarily requires data infrastructure (host satisfaction metrics, proposal acceptance rates) rather than further user validation.

cross_process_insights.insight: The platform needs BILATERAL commitment architecture, not just unilateral optimization. The design-stack (inside-out) optimized each side independently: easy proposals for hosts (communicates-005), clear pipelines for guests (guest-communicates-005). The reverse-benchmark (outside-in) reveals that the RELATIONSHIP between host and guest — the mutual commitment, structured communication, similarity-matched validation — is what the entire category has left unbuilt. The strongest design interventions create mutual investment between two specific people, not just individual ease for each party.
cross_process_insights.implication: Future design work should evaluate every element through a bilateral lens: does this create investment from BOTH parties? Individual-optimization elements (cognitive ease, smart defaults) remain essential but are necessary-not-sufficient. The competitive moat is in the bilateral architecture.

cross_process_insights.insight: Two theoretical frameworks converge on the same design principle from different directions: Kahneman's System 1 trust gates (design-stack) and Cialdini's commitment escalation (reverse-benchmark) both prescribe that every transition must reference what came before. Kahneman says this because associative coherence requires familiar anchors. Cialdini says this because commitment compounds only when each step references the previous commitment. Every transition is simultaneously a trust gate AND a commitment bridge.
cross_process_insights.implication: Transition design specifications should include BOTH a cognitive ease requirement (familiar anchor in first 2 seconds) AND a commitment reference requirement (explicit callback to what the user previously committed to).

cross_process_insights.insight: The design-stack identified trust as primarily PROCESS-BASED (communicates-003: credit checks, vetting, pre-authorization). The reverse-benchmark identified trust as also SOCIAL-BASED (rb-ui-002: reviews from similar others, rb-ui-006: peer validation). The complete trust architecture requires both: process trust says 'the system is reliable,' social trust says 'people like you succeeded here.' Neither alone is sufficient. Process trust without social trust feels institutional. Social trust without process trust feels like marketing.
cross_process_insights.implication: The Trust Credential Stack (communicates-003) should be extended to include social proof signals alongside process signals. For example, credit check verification accompanied by 'Hosts who receive vetted guests rate their experience 4.8/5.' This combines process mechanism with social validation.

cross_process_insights.insight: The design-stack's evidence base (call transcripts) is strong for pre-stay interactions but weak for post-stay and retention. The reverse-benchmark's evidence base (competitive analysis + Cialdini) is strong for post-stay and retention psychology but has no direct user evidence. The two pipelines have COMPLEMENTARY BLIND SPOTS. This means post-stay elements (rb-ui-004) have the lowest cross-validated confidence and the highest need for future direct-evidence collection.
cross_process_insights.implication: Prioritize collecting post-stay user research (guest interviews after checkout, review text analysis, rebooking behavior data) to close the evidence gap. Until this data exists, post-stay elements should be treated as high-potential hypotheses rather than validated design requirements.

cross_process_insights.insight: The review system is the most under-designed element in both pipelines. The design-stack identified the collection problem (guest-communicates-007: per-stay review fatigue). The reverse-benchmark identified the display problem (rb-ui-002: aggregate reviews waste the similarity principle). Neither pipeline has addressed the MIDDLE layer: review prompt design that deliberately collects similarity-taggable metadata enabling the People-Like-You filter. The collection → content → display chain has a missing link.
cross_process_insights.implication: A future run should design the review prompt specifically to capture: stay purpose, duration context, priority satisfaction ('How was the workspace?'), and guest self-identification. This metadata is what bridges batched collection (design-stack) and similarity-filtered display (reverse-benchmark).

new_tokens_flagged.conflict: Library uses accent: #2d5a3d (green). No purple in token system.
Library specifies serif: Instrument Serif, sans: Outfit, mono: IBM Plex Mono.
Library uses surface-warm: #fdfcfa (neutral warm) vs. rb-ui's cool purple tint.
Library uses border: #e2dfd9 (warm gray) vs. rb-ui's cool gray.
Library uses ink-muted: #8a857e (warm) vs. rb-ui's cool neutral.
Library uses ink-soft: #4a4640 (warm) vs. rb-ui's cool neutral.

token_compliance.recommendation: The rb-ui elements use a purple-accent, cool-neutral design system that diverges from the library's warm-neutral, green-accent token system. This creates VISUAL FRAGMENTATION if both are implemented simultaneously. Resolution: (1) If purple is the confirmed brand evolution for the product, update tokens.json with purple accent tokens and cool-neutral ink variants. (2) If the warm palette should remain canonical, re-skin all rb-ui elements to use library tokens before implementation. (3) Replace Inter/DM Sans with Outfit (library sans-serif). The visual LOGIC of the rb-ui elements (hierarchy, spacing, progressive disclosure) is sound regardless of specific tokens. The conflict is brand-level, not structural. This should be escalated to the design team as a product-level decision before any rb-ui element enters development.

discovery.source: design-stack (works-001, works-004, communicates-003, communicates-006, feels-001) + reverse-benchmark (rb-ui-005). Gap: no element addresses the Craigslist-to-platform trust handoff identified in Layer 2 discovery-004.

evaluation.source: design-stack (works-001, works-004, works-005, communicates-003, feels-001, feels-002) + reverse-benchmark (rb-ui-002). Gap: no element addresses the one-way mirror (disappoint-010) — guest self-disclosure during evaluation.

onboarding.source: design-stack only (works-001, works-002, communicates-001, communicates-003, communicates-006, feels-001). No reverse-benchmark elements — Cialdini's commitment/social proof lens applies more to later phases.

listing_creation.source: design-stack only (works-002, works-003, works-005, works-006, communicates-004, communicates-005). Most covered phase in the library.

pricing.source: design-stack (works-006, communicates-002, feels-002, guest-feels-002). No reverse-benchmark elements — Cialdini's lens doesn't focus on pricing mechanics.

proposal_mgmt.source: design-stack (communicates-005, guest-communicates-005, guest-behaves-004) + reverse-benchmark (rb-ui-001, rb-ui-003, rb-ui-006). Strongest cross-process coverage — design-stack provides cognitive efficiency layer, reverse-benchmark provides psychological commitment layer.

active_lease.source: design-stack (guest-works-001, guest-works-003, guest-feels-001, guest-communicates-007) + reverse-benchmark (rb-ui-004 — post-stay edge). Gap: no element provides mid-stay engagement touchpoints (Cialdini's commitment reinforcement) — the 'silent stay' (disappoint-005) is identified but not fully resolved.

retention.source: design-stack (communicates-006 — agent continuity as retention baseline) + reverse-benchmark (rb-ui-004 — identity line as retention seed). Weakest phase in the combined library. A future run should focus specifically on retention architecture.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Analyze post-stay guest interactions — review text, rebooking conversations, churn interviews — through a Cialdini commitment/consistency lens to validate rb-ui-004 (Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge) with direct user evidence. This is the highest-potential element with the weakest validation.
next_run_recommendations.reason: rb-ui-004 addresses the highest-potential gap (post-review emotional peak) but has the weakest transcript validation (disappoint-007 rated 'weak'). The design-stack's call transcript base cannot validate post-stay psychology. Direct post-stay evidence would either confirm or redirect this element.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Analyze Furnished Finder through the same Cialdini Ch.3-4 lens to validate that commitment and social proof gaps are category-wide, not Airbnb-specific. Furnished Finder serves traveling nurses (medium-term, purpose-specific) — closer to Split Lease's use case.
next_run_recommendations.reason: All five opportunities claim 'entire category' gaps based primarily on Airbnb analysis. Validating against a closer competitor would confirm gaps are structural to the category model, not specific to Airbnb's mass-market design choices.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Run a guest-focused pass analyzing guest call transcripts through Cialdini Ch.3-4 to validate the similarity-filtered social proof hypothesis (rb-ui-002). Search for guest quotes about how they evaluate reviews and whether similarity matters.
next_run_recommendations.reason: rb-ui-002 has strong framework support and competitive evidence but only moderate transcript validation. Direct guest quotes about review behavior would significantly strengthen or redirect this element.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Design the review prompt to collect similarity-taggable metadata — the missing middle layer between batched collection (guest-communicates-007) and similarity-filtered display (rb-ui-002). Prompt must capture stay purpose, duration context, and priority satisfaction.
next_run_recommendations.reason: The review system has collection and display elements from both pipelines but no content-design element. Without deliberate metadata collection, rb-ui-002's filter chips have no data to filter on.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Resolve the token system divergence (purple vs. green accent, Inter/DM Sans vs. Outfit/Instrument Serif, cool vs. warm neutrals) before implementing any rb-ui elements. Produce a unified token set.
next_run_recommendations.reason: Visual fragmentation between existing library elements and new rb-ui elements would undermine the warm surface continuity prescribed by looks-001. This is a product-level decision that blocks implementation.

next_run_recommendations.recommendation: Analyze Airbnb through Cialdini Chapters 1-2 (Reciprocity) and Chapters 5-6 (Liking, Authority) to discover opportunities in dimensions this run did not cover.
